186033380.review:
TL;DR: 

Auch über 10 Jahre nach Release lohnt es sich noch, Civilization V zu spielen – wer die zahlreichen DLCs möchte, sollte aber lieber auf einen Sale warten, da sonst alles schnell zu teuer wird.

Ich spiele Civilization V nun schon seit einer ganzen Weile und bin immer noch absolut begeistert. Von Anfang an läuft alles sehr flüssig, und erst in den späteren Zeitaltern kann es auf wirklich großen Karten ein wenig dauern, bis die KI ihre Züge berechnet hat. Das finde ich jedoch gut verschmerzbar, weil das Spiel dann auch richtig an Komplexität gewinnt.

Die Grafik empfinde ich keineswegs als altbacken. Sie ist zweckmäßig und gleichzeitig hübsch genug, um auch nach vielen Spielstunden nicht zu langweilen. Außerdem haben die unterschiedlichen Anführer jeweils ihren eigenen Stil, was immer wieder für frische Strategien sorgt. Ich lerne selbst nach der x-ten Partie noch neue Kniffe dazu – und genau das macht auch nach über 100 Runden unheimlich viel Spaß.

„Civ“ ist und bleibt für mich ein grandioses Strategieerlebnis: Aufbauen, Expandieren, Diplomatie führen oder Krieg anzetteln – die Möglichkeiten sind riesig. Auch die Achievements motivieren mich, neue Taktiken auszuprobieren, ohne dabei frustrierend schwierig zu sein.

Der einzige Negativpunkt, den ich habe, sind die zahlreichen DLCs, die in der Summe recht kostspielig werden können. Mein Tipp: einfach auf einen Sale warten, dann bekommt man alles zu einem viel faireren Preis.

Wer Rundentaktik liebt, kann mit Civilization V auch nach all den Jahren nichts falsch machen. Es begeistert mich immer noch, und ich bin mir sicher, dass es auch anderen Strategiefans genauso ergehen wird.

185953764.review:
A classic bottomless time-hole / digitalized crack software. 

What makes it is two things:

1) The aesthetics. Everything from leader screens to units immerse you in the worlds. Borders and terrains flow smoothly over each other. Animals on the map move and make sound. Huge soundtrack library tailored to war and peace times, and to the particular civs. Cities are carefully generated around terrain, reflect their size, have architecture particular to civs, and physically render wonders you build. 1000 hours later, I still get a kick out of zooming in on my cities to see them thriving. Not to mention that even at max settings, just about any computer made within the last 10 years should handle it just fine. 

2) The learning curve. Every new game is incredibly easy to pick up. There's a big button that queues everything you need to do, and new mechanics get added steadily, so you can get used to them one at a time. Finer mechanics are by default done automatically, but fully adjustable if you want to more strongly coordinate. Difficulty levels are well tuned, so that consistently beating one makes the next a well-matched challenge. 

Overall, a true masterclass in game design on just about every front, and very well worth the price. 

Also, for the record, I haven't had any issues with launching lol.

185948381.review:
Sid Meier's Civilization V is one of those games I kept coming back to over and over. It's a turn-based strategy game where you guide a civilization from the dawn of time to the modern age, and no two games ever feel quite the same. Whether you're building wonders, waging wars, or making allies, there's always something to keep you engaged.

The gameplay is super satisfying, especially with the way the hex-based maps and combat work. It makes planning out your moves and strategy feel rewarding, whether you're expanding your empire or just trying to survive a surprise war. The expansions like Gods & Kings and Brave New World made the game even better, adding religion, trade, and diplomacy systems that gave it more depth.

That said, I never managed to unlock all the achievements, even after playing a ton. Some of them are just really specific or require a crazy amount of dedication and the game gets a bit repetitive if you play it for so long. But honestly, there's always another challenge waiting, even if you're not a completionist, and it's definitely worth playing.

If you’re into strategy games or just love a game that lets you lose track of time while building your own version of history, Civ V is a fantastic choice. It’s not perfect, but it’s an experience I don’t regret sinking so many hours into.

How to Fix Civilization Not Working After Uninstalling the 2K Launcher!
If Civilization stopped working after the Windows 24H2 update, follow these steps carefully in order:

Step 1: Delete the game's cache.

Navigate to: My PC -> Documents.
Find the folder named after the game and delete it.
Step 2: Add the game folder to Windows Security exceptions.

Open Windows Security.
Go to Virus & Threat Protection -> Manage Settings (under "Virus & Threat Protection settings").
Scroll to Exclusions and click Add or Remove Exclusions.
Add the game folder to the exclusions.
How to find the folder path:
Go to your Steam Library, right-click the game, select Properties -> Local Files -> Browse Local Files.
Step 3: Change launcher compatibility.

Right-click the game’s launcher icon.
Select Properties -> Compatibility.
Set compatibility mode to Windows 8.
Click Apply.
Step 4: Clear Steam cache.

In the Steam app, go to Settings (top-left corner).
Navigate to the In-Game section.
Select Clear Cache.
Step 5: Verify game files.

In your Steam Library, right-click the game.
Select Properties -> Installed Files -> Verify Integrity of Game Files.
Step 6: Delete launcher files.

In the game folder, delete all launcher-related files (e.g., launcher executables).
Step 7: Verify game files again.

Repeat Step 5 to restore any deleted files.
Step 8: Restart your PC.

Step 9: Roll back the Windows update (if necessary).
If the game still doesn’t work:

Go to Settings -> Windows Update -> Advanced Options -> Recovery -> Go Back to a Previous Version.
Step 10: Wait a day.
If none of the above works, be patient. Sometimes the issue resolves itself after 24 hours.

Good luck!

Classic game, still works well and I'd recommend it.
One warning: They removed the 2K launcher, which caused problems for many people. 
Fix: right click game, manage, browse local files. Look at 3 files, CivilizationV, Civilization_DX11, and Civilization_Tablet. Back on steam, verify your game files and try running DirectX11. If it fails, do it again until those 3 files have a "date modified" date of the same day you're updating them. Then exit steam, restart computer and run DirectX11, it may take a few tries. Hope this helps.

185520604.review:
I played this 10 years ago and decided to try it again with my current computer. It did not run on the first try. After reading online about the trouble with Windows 11, I finally got the DX9 version to run. The DX11 version would never load and I doubt they will patch it, so I can't recommend this to anyone buying it new.
After installing the game, verify the files under the game properties in Steam. Go to the Steam file location on pc, locate CivilizationV.exe, right click and choose properties. Click the compatibility tab, check the box "Run this program in compatibility mode for" and choose Windows 7. Double click the exe file and Civ5 installed the old version of DirectX and VCRedist, and started fine. If you get a popup asking which version, choose DX9. Using the desktop icon will avoid the popup.
It's a decent game, but several things are really annoying. Using the quick version of the game is a must unless you want a 10 hour game. Cities cannot automate their production which leads to a lot of clicking late game. For unit movements, the game has trouble figuring out multiple steps.

185322558.review:
If Civilization 5 isn't launching after the recent update where they removed the 2k launcher do the following.
1.	Go to your steam library
2.	Right click on the game
3.	Click on properties
4.	Click on installed files
5.	At the top right of the window you will see the location of installed files, click on the browse
6.	In the directory right click on either executable you wish to run. CivilizationV.exe or CivilizationV_DX11.exe
7.	Click on properties
8.	Click on compatibility
9.	Enable compatibility mode with windows 8 or 7 mode
10.	Click apply
11.	Run the game through the selected executable in the folder not the play button through steam.
12.	Enjoy

It has been reported that this additional function might help with making the game run with some individuals.

In the compatibility screen with step 8, enable run as administrator. This should also help with getting the game to run.

185199441.review:
Also ich hab mal wieder paar Sessions hingelegt. Ja, Civ 5 hat viele Schwächen im Vergleich zum meinem All time favorite "Civ2".
- die Zufriedenheit oszilliert ständig in einer nicht nachvollziehbaren Weise
- ganze Imperien führen Krieg ohne Geld (tausende im Minus)
- Atombomben bzw. deren Bomber lassen sich nicht anfangen (nichtmal mit Jets der Moderne)
- Kein WW1 oder WW2 Multiplayer Szenario (die ausm workshop verändern entweder das komplette game oder sind scheiße)
- generell keine Multiplayer-Szenarien - nichtmal mit DLC! (Nur über Workshop... WTF?!)
- Politik ist komplett bescheuert - du wirst von einem anderen Staat invasiert, schlägst zurück und bist dann der Kriegstreiber xD 
- Weder im Singleplayer noch im Multiplayer kann man einstellen dass man nur bis zu Zeitalter X forschen will.


ABER auf der Kehrseite des ganzen, kann man mit einer normalen Partie sehr viel Spaß haben. Jenseits der Macken ist diplomatie im Singleplayer ganz okay. Staaten, die man ordentlich buttert, bleiben einem auch treu. Bei militärischer Überlegenheit hat man meistens auch Ruhe. Es gibt viele coole Volkseigene Einheiten (leider nur für eine handvoll Epochen), alle Einheiten sind gut gebalanced, mit dem Addon BNW gibt es endlich auch wieder fernkampf-infantrie, Die Grafik ist schön, die Animationen nett, die Musik klasse. Man kann sehr viele Stunden Freude an diesem Teil haben. Er bietet Spieltiefe ohne den Bildschirm wie Teil VI komplett zu fluten und man braucht keine lange Eingewöhnungsphase wenn man von einem Vorgänger kommt. 

Im Sale oder bei <=15€ ist das meiner Meinung nach ein Must-Have.

184836350.review:
if you're having trouble launching do the following

Fix
Go to the Civilization V folder on your PC (in Steam: Select Civilization V in your library -> Gear icon -> Manage -> Browse local files).

In this folder, there are three executables named CivilizationV.exe CivilizationV_DX11.exe and CivilizationV_Tablet.exe (there's also a fourth one called Launcher.exe which you can ignore). These are the three executables which need to be updated by Steam.

Remove these three executables completely.

After removing the executables, go to Steam and verify the game files (select Civilization V in your library -> Gear icon -> Properties -> Installed Files -> Verify integrity of game files). This process will re-download the three executables. Note: the game won't work yet, this is just a way to keep track of the updating process.

After verifying the files, you should see the three executables again in the Civilization V folder. Take note of the time at which these files were modified, which will make the next steps a bit easier. Keep this folder open for now.

Now, try to launch the game normally via Steam. You can select any of the DirectX versions.

When the game is being launched, pay attention to the Civilization V folder and look for any changes to the executables. Sometimes you will see that one of the three executables will be updated. You can verify this by looking at the time at which an executable got modified; if the file is newer than the previously downloaded executables, it has been updated.

Wait until you can press 'Play' again.

Repeat steps 6-8 until all three executables have been updated. (For me this took 10-15 tries).

When all three executables have been updated, you can launch the game again and it should boot right up.


**MAKE SURE YOUR YOUR GAME FOLDER ISNT SET TO READ ONLY**

KEEP LAUNCHING UNTIL AN ADMIN PROMPT TO INSTALL SOMETHING POPS UP

CREDIT /u/causa-sui - on reddit

184825899.review: I notice a lot of ppl debating between getting the full DLC bundle for Civ V or VI. From the perspective of somebody whose been playing both pretty diligently recently and have watched plenty of video's on the matter, I must say that in terms of the un-modded game play, Civ V is going to be a lot easier to understand mechanics and strategy wise than Civ VI, however it still has plenty of depth and is more aesthetically pleasing imo; however, Civ VI increased complexity and ability to make achieving other victory conditions like religious and cultural more plausible/competitive (I found Civ V was heavily geared towards the scientific victory) is what makes it stand out for me. So, if you don't plan on modding the game, I recommend Civ V just because the trade off for more complex game play with Civ VI does not outweigh the lack of quality in comparison to it's predecessor (although it's not a major difference, but some things in the newer game might bother you or be too confusing in the beginning). As for which game to choose if you plan on modding it, i'd have to go with Civ VI. After playing the game for a bit, I found a mod pack someone created (it was in the popular section and included all the "juicy" mechanic's based and visual mods I wanted), and it just transformed the game by adding more natural and artificial wonders, better water effects, denser vegetation, enhanced tile "biomes", etc. It literally made the game into another Civ VII. It did take a solid match to figure out how all the mods affected everything and getting used to the new complexity, but it's so worth it. Hopefully my review helps ppl with making a decision between both games based on their own personal desires and circumstance. Thanks for reading and enjoy your day.

--Update as of 1/6/2025--
I have managed to get the game running again, for how long I am unsure, but I am going to share how I was able to. For W11 users.

Whether this has any effect or not, you need to get the legacy launcher.

Select CIV 5 in your library, right click, go to properties, go to the Betas tab. In the text box for beta access, enter in "ineedlegacyaccess" without the "s, hit Check Code. You'll receive confirmation.

After doing that, verify the game files. Then go to your Steam settings, find Downloads tab, and hit Clear Download Cache. Steam will restart, if it doesn't, relaunch manually. Then go to CIV 5 in your library, click play, launch DX10/11 version. It should then start running.

This may not work for everyone, you may need to even reinstall the game first. I'm not 100% certain, but this is what has worked for me.

Best of luck and God bless.

--Original Review--
After a long hiatus from Civ V, I got back into the game last month and began having a blast. Unfortunately, right around before the new year, I was unable to launch the game. Stuck updating the executable out of nowhere. I had tried nearly everything. Verifying, clearing cache, reinstalling fresh, and so much more. Even on two different operating systems (W10, W11) and yet I have been unable to resume playing the game.

What's sad is, I had encountered it multiple times, sometimes I was able to fix it, and resume my game, but then on the same day, it would resume being broken. Other issues I have encountered included the game just straight up not wanting to reach the main menu after launch, only for then, upon fixing that, to resume encountering the updating executable issue. At this point though. I have entered the new year defeated, unable to play the game.

I'm pissed, and disappointed to say the least. Civ V was my only and favorite game in the series, with many hours and memories, and while I have contemplated purchasing Civ VI, not only do I feel completely turned off by the graphics, the UI, and some... suspicious design choices, I personally believe they do not deserve any bit of money, or statistics. For this is unacceptable. It feels like I, along with many other fans of Civ V got the middle finger from 2K.

Under normal circumstances, I would give a pass, as legitimate issues can happen with games, but given the state of video games in the past few years, and the horrible, disgusting, and greedy business practices that companies and corporations make, I feel though as if this was intentional.

Should Civ V actually get fixed. I will gladly resume playing it, otherwise. I am done.

184609203.review:
After 1,000+ hours, I can safely recommend Civ5 to everyone. However, I thought it was unplayable after the newest update and this "Updating Executable" issue everyone on a newer system seems to be dealing with. I wrote a discussion thread about how to fix this for players who have already bought it.

The tl;dr is to open Local Files under Manage by right clicking Civ5 in your library, delete CivilizationV_DX11, and Verify Files under Properties and Install Files to reinstall it. Keep local files open and launch the game and see if DX11 updates with a new Modified Time. If it does, Delete the Launcher, CivilizationV, and CivilizationV_Tablet files. Make three copies of DX11, and rename them to the files you deleted. You should be able to run the game after doing so. I hope this helps past, present, and future players!

184234635.review:
The game doesn't launch due to a permission error after the 2K Launcher removal.

Here a to-do list to fix the game (this worked for me):
1. Reinstall Civ5
2. Find, in the game folder, the following execs: CivilizationV_DX11.exe; LaunchPad.exe; Launcher.exe
3. For each file, change Compatibility Mode to Windows 7 and tick "Run this program as an administrator" (Right-Click > Properties > Compatibility)
4. Apply and Play

Extra Step if this still didn't work: Remove the "Read-Only" attribute from the My Documents folder (Right-Click > Properties). Didn't need to do this, but found a reddit comment that talked about doing this. Props to u/hurfery

That's it. Great game, but you need a IT Bachelor to make it work now.

184158162.review:
After playing Sid Meier's Civilization V for the past 11 years, I can confidently say it’s not just my favorite strategy game—it’s my favorite video game of all time. No matter how many hours I pour into it, the thrill of leading a civilization from the dawn of man to the space age never gets old. Whether you’re battling it out against AI or facing off with friends in multiplayer, Civ 5 delivers an incredible mix of strategy, replayability, and satisfaction that has stood the test of time.

A Masterpiece of Strategy:

At its core, Civ 5 is about choices. Every decision—where to settle your cities, which technologies to prioritize, how to handle diplomacy—affects the fate of your civilization. The gameplay is brilliantly layered, with a balance of military conquest, cultural growth, scientific advancement, and diplomatic finesse. There’s no single “right way” to play, which makes every game feel unique.

The turn-based system ensures you have time to think through your moves, while the depth of its mechanics keeps you constantly engaged. You’re always weighing risk and reward, adjusting to new threats, or capitalizing on unexpected opportunities. It’s a game that rewards both careful planning and the ability to adapt.

Perfect Alone or With Friends:

Civilization V shines equally in single-player and multiplayer. Playing alone lets you immerse yourself in long, sprawling campaigns, facing off against AI leaders with distinct personalities and playstyles. It’s the perfect game for those quiet evenings when you just want to lose yourself in strategy.

But multiplayer adds an entirely different layer of fun. Competing (or cooperating) with friends introduces new levels of tension, mind games, and hilarity. Watching alliances form and crumble, racing to a victory condition, or simply trash-talking over the mic makes for unforgettable gaming moments. Few things are as satisfying as outmaneuvering a friend to claim a cultural or military victory—or the chaos of realizing you’ve been double-crossed.

Endless Replayability:

One of the reasons Civ 5 remains so addictive after all these years is its replayability. Each map feels fresh, thanks to the random map generator, diverse starting locations, and the wide array of civilizations to choose from. Whether you’re playing as the science-focused Korea, the militaristic Zulu, or the cultural powerhouse France, each civ has unique traits and units that make every game feel different.

Add to that the expansions (Gods & Kings and Brave New World), which introduce religion, espionage, trade routes, and even more victory conditions, and the possibilities become nearly endless.

A Timeless Classic:

The visuals, while not cutting-edge anymore, still hold up beautifully. The hexagonal tiles give the game a clean, modern look, and the interface is intuitive and easy to navigate. Meanwhile, the music and leader screens bring each civilization to life, immersing you in the world-building of the game.

Even after more than a decade, Civ 5 feels as fun, polished, and rewarding as ever. It’s a testament to the game’s brilliant design that no matter how many hours you’ve played, you’re still discovering new strategies and approaches.

Final Thoughts:

Sid Meier’s Civilization V isn’t just a game—it’s a lifelong obsession. Its depth, complexity, and endless replayability make it a true masterpiece of the strategy genre. Whether you’re a solo player who loves crafting the perfect empire or a fan of competitive multiplayer with friends, Civ 5 has something for everyone.

After 11 years, it’s still my go-to game and likely always will be. If you haven’t experienced it yet, do yourself a favor and start your first campaign. Just be prepared to lose track of time—just one more turn is real, and it’s glorious.

Rating: 10/10

- If so far is ok, add all DLC and try.

183615064.review:
basically one of the best (non-existent) board games ever made for computers (and consoles). Multiplayer requires a time commitment, as its too hard to stop once you're going and while it does allow for up to like 12 people to play online, it also allows for people to play hot seat, and share the computer.

The Civilization Series ebbs and flows with complexity but at its core is a hyper accessible civilization board game that takes you through the ages of human advancement. Choosing a leader at the start is actually choosing a slightly cartoonified representation of this 2000+ year old civilization, even allowing you to take now extinct or absorbed civilizations into the 21st century, like Shoshone Natives, Babylonians, Aztecs, or the Roman Empire. Each civ choice has a set of benefits, exclusive equipment, and or military units, each useful for a specific era of gameplay, however, just because you started high on the leaderboard means you'll win, nor does starting low mean you'll lose and the general shared technology paths keep everyone balanced by their own choices/necessities.

General gameplay involves establishing a capitol city, and fueling it with resources that either provide happiness. culture, faith, science, or production, as well as protecting it from other civilazations or in the early game, barbarians. To do so, you'll need to choose productions in your city, deciding between new units or the more score increasing/skill enabling city building/upgrades, from defensive walls to the city library, each feeding into one of four strategies of winning/staying alive: Culture, Science, Faith, or Dominence. Winning by culture involves having your civ be too valuable a historic or otherwise significant society, science by being the smartest, faith by creating a religion and spreading your own faith through the world, and dominance through military might and physical control. Don't forget gold/money, as a civ that is losing money is also losing happiness, and a resource to buy units or improvements instantly for the next turn.

Each turn lets you move or place units through the world, exploring the map or preparing for war with another civ, or moving new settlers to establish a new city/workers to build improvements and harness resources around your land. You can also choose scientific research to persue and productions to undertake to add to your units or resources, each requiring an amount of turns to fully access.

Even without DlC it will take lots of your time and be very fun, not to mention very good with friends--each Civ game kinda sucks when playing online (they all desync ALL THE TIME, meaning you see a loading screen often as the game resets). Civ 5 has that problem but desyncs tend to resolve within seconds, making them not too hard to deal with until you get deep into a session (about 2-3 hours in, save, have everyone quit, and then restart the game.) But even while playing alone, theres lots of fun to be had here and on virtually any device.
